so for example we turned on an
accessibility linter
we use eslant plugin we originally set
this at the warning level
so as soon as an engineer makes a commit
they will get back a list of
accessibility errors that they might
have in the files that they touched
and we keep these at a warning level for
now because we know we have so much tech
debt that
we can't afford to put it at the error
level and block people because we would
be blocking everyone
but eventually as we work through this
tech debt we will be converting it from
the warning to the error level
and blocking people from making any pr
that has an accessibility issue
that the linter can check for
we also really heavily prioritize an
accessible design system
and so we have a component library built
in react
called oui for optimize the ui and
a huge part of my job is ensuring that
each of those components
stays accessible and becomes accessible
if it isn't already so that
when engineers are utilizing those
components
we can at least guarantee that that
portion of the ui is accessible that
particular component
and then we can worry about the big
picture stuff like focus management
and keyboard navigation and ensure that
each of these components is built into a
larger
accessible feature we also include

drop down with a keyboard
that kind of thing so that our

we also make accessibility a prominent

so for jira tickets we have an

this phase of action is your first start
to make sure that you are making

scaling those changes
and so you might have fixed the graph in
one place
but not all of the graphs are accessible
and so
i foresee us moving into a scaling phase

entire legacy code base to ensure that

okay our product is decently accessible
